item.title: Editorial: Geoscience in a time of pandemics
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
Source: Tennant, J. P., Illingworth, S., Stewart, I., and von Elverfeldt, K.: Editorial: Geoscience in a time of pandemics, Geosci. Commun., 3, 71–72, https://doi.org/10.5194/gc-3-71-2020, 2020. We, the executive editors at Geoscience Communication, sincerely hope that this message finds you and your loved ones in good health. We are in the midst of a global-health crisis, […]

The post Editorial: Geoscience in a time of pandemics appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: Comments for Times Higher Education: University of California break with Elsevier tipped to boost ‘global revolt’
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
Times Higher Education just published an article about the latest in the ongoing ‘Elsevier versus everyone else’ saga. It contains a quote from me, so I decided to post my full unedited response to Ellie, the writer, here for full transparency (with permission). Her questions are in italics, and my responses in normal text. How […]

The post Comments for Times Higher Education: University of California break with Elsevier tipped to boost ‘global revolt’ appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: Weekly stuff roundup: 9th March, 2018
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
Welcome to the first weekly roundup of vaguely interesting stuff that happened in the last week! Enjoy, and let me know if I’ve missed anything out. Palaeontology stuff Knoll et al. (2018): A fossil of a juvenile enantiornithine tells us about the skeletal development in early birds during the Cretaceous period. LeBlanc et al. (2018): […]

The post Weekly stuff roundup: 9th March, 2018 appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: 13: Peer Review: Anonymity Versus Identification (III)
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
This is adapted from our recent paper in F1000 Research, entitled “A multi-disciplinary perspective on emergent and future innovations in peer review.” Due to its rather monstrous length, I’ll be posting chunks of the text here in sequence over the next few weeks to help disseminate it in more easily digestible bites. Enjoy! This section describes […]

The post 13: Peer Review: Anonymity Versus Identification (III) appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: September has been very busy..
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
So, I’ve been back in Berlin now for almost 3 months after taking 10 months off to work-travel. And crikey, what a time it has been! There’s been so much happening recently, and we’re in the middle of conference season too. Here’s just a list of stuff I’ve written or been involved in the last […]

The post September has been very busy.. appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: Trust me, I’m a scientist.
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
Why should people trust the published scientific record? Imagine this hypothetical, but potentially very real, conversation with a non-academic: 1: “This research paper has been published, and therefore is scientifically valid.” 2: “But it’s paywalled, I can’t access it. How do I know it’s valid?” 1: “Because it has been peer reviewed.” 2. “Can you […]

The post Trust me, I’m a scientist. appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: Other stuff wot I wrote
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
As I’m sure many of you are aware, this is not the only platform I write on. This is my own personal blog, which explains the perpetually low quality of the ramblings on here. I also write a lot for ScienceOpen, and also the PLOS Paleo Community. The former of these includes a lot of […]

The post Other stuff wot I wrote appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: Science, echo chambers, and why facts are never enough.
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
Social media is transforming the way we engage with one another, often striking a delicate balance between bringing ourselves closer together and isolating each other. What social media has shown us is that humans love interacting with other people. We love having others agree with us, and we love jumping on social bandwagons and lashing out […]

The post Science, echo chambers, and why facts are never enough. appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: The original Introduction for my thesis
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
One month ago, I defended my PhD thesis and passed my viva exam, proving that basically anyone can become a Doctor these days. I got ‘minor revisions’ as a result, which was just to shorten the abstract to institutional format requirements, and cut the waffle from the Introduction. I kinda liked the waffle though, as […]

The post The original Introduction for my thesis appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.

item.title: My interview with Imperial College on the rise and fall of ancient dinosaur-eating crocodiles
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
While back in London recently for my PhD viva, the opportunity came up to speak with the Communications Office at Imperial College about some of my research. Naturally I pounced at the chance to discuss my research and broadcast it to a wider audience. The short audio for the interview is now online here, and […]

The post My interview with Imperial College on the rise and fall of ancient dinosaur-eating crocodiles appeared first on Green Tea and Velociraptors.
